text.p: The following are the main stories from Friday morning's Austrian newspapers:
DER STANDARD
- Austria's industry is improving due to rising foreign demand and the appreciation of the U.S. dollar. However, the current account deficit is growing faster than expected.
- GiroCredit's chief says he would accept a partner to participate in postal savings bank PSK.
- Austria's Health Minister Barbara Prammer has installed an import ban on genetically manipulated corn.
- Transport Minister Caspar Einem has promised open access to telecommunications licences. The liberalisation of Austria's telecoms market should lead to lower prices.
- Austria celebrates its second bronze medal at the world skiing championships in Sestriere after Mario Reiter took third place in the combined skiing event.
DIE PRESSE
- The Social Democrats have put forward former Chancellor Franz Vranitzky as a possible candidate for the European Central Bank.
- Chancellor Viktor Klima made his first official visit abroad to the Netherlands, breaking with tradition as Austria's chancellors always visited Switzerland first.
- Austrian baker Ankerbrot will remain independent and jobs will be kept safe, says its new owner German baking giant Muellerbrot.
- Lauda Air says it is open for further cooperation with Austrian Airlines. Meanwhile, Lufthansa's representative in Lauda Air's supervisory board has quit.
KURIER
- Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York, was the celebrated guest at yesterday's annual Vienna Opera Ball.
- A new takeover law to better protect small shareholders should be ready by the summer.
- Austria's construction industry is reporting the lowest number of orders in 22 years, according to latest data.
- Austria's oil and chemicals group OMV is planning to expand its petrol station network abroad.
SALZBURGER NACHRICHTEN
- Motor engineer Steyr Antriebstechnik is planning to cut 135 jobs.
WIRTSCHAFTSBLATT
- German bank Bayern Hypo sees a possibility of buying into Austria's Oberbank.
